dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, is Biden seriously proposing a new tax on all foreign-made goods? Because, um, that sounds pretty wild, doesn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, is Biden seriously proposing a new tax on all foreign-made goods? Because, um, that sounds pretty wild, doesn't it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, Host_A, it's actually part of a much broader, uh, $2 trillion plan. It's about revitalizing infrastructure and, you know, manufacturing here, and creating jobs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, Host_A, it's actually part of a much broader, uh, two dollars trillion plan. It's about revitalizing infrastructure and, you know, manufacturing here, and creating jobs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The $2 trillion Biden will ask Congress to approve for his American Jobs Plan will be spent over a period of eight years and paid for with tax hikes over a period of 15 years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Two trillion dollars? My gosh. Like, how are they even going to pay for that? More taxes, I'm guessing?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Two trillion dollars? My gosh. Like, how are they even going to pay for that? More taxes, I'm guessing?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, definitely tax hikes. They're looking at raising the corporate rate, for example, from 21% to 28%, and also increasing the global minimum tax on US companies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, definitely tax hikes. They're looking at raising the corporate rate, for example, from twenty one percent to twenty eight percent, and also increasing the global minimum tax on U S companies.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To help pay for all that spending, the Biden administration is expected to propose a series of major tax changes including raising the corporate rate from 21% to 28% and raising the global minimum tax.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so it's, like, mostly big businesses then? Not, um, ordinary people?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so it's, like, mostly big businesses then? Not, um, ordinary people?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, the White House clarified that the individual tax hikes they're proposing are, um, only for those making over $750,000 per year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, the White House clarified that the individual tax hikes they're proposing are, um, only for those making over seven hundred fifty thousand dollars per year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, okay. So it's not like a sales tax on my, um, imported shoes. But the article mentioned a tax on foreign-made goods specifically.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, okay. So it's not like a sales tax on my, um, imported shoes. But the article mentioned a tax on foreign-made goods specifically.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That particular bit is more about making it, um, more expensive for American companies to produce goods and services overseas. The goal there is to, like, encourage domestic manufacturing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That particular bit is more about making it, um, more expensive for American companies to produce goods and services overseas. The goal there is to, like, encourage domestic manufacturing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Biden also wants to encourage domestic manufacturing by making it more expensive for American companies to produce goods and services overseas.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Got it. Domestic manufacturing, jobs. But what exactly are we getting for two trillion dollars? Like, just roads?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Got it. Domestic manufacturing, jobs. But what exactly are we getting for two trillion dollars? Like, just roads?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Roads and bridges, absolutely. But also, um, $174 billion for electric vehicles, over a hundred billion for clean drinking water, and the same for expanding broadband and the power grid.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Roads and bridges, absolutely. But also, um, one hundred seventy four dollars billion for electric vehicles, over a hundred billion for clean drinking water, and the same for expanding broadband and the power grid.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Included in that $2 trillion is $621 billion for transportation infrastructure like roads and bridges, with $174 billion of that set aside for the electric vehicle market, $111 billion for clean drinking water, $100 billion for expanding broadband and $100 billion for power infrastructure like the electric grid.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. I bet, um, Republicans are going to hate this price tag, huh?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. I bet, um, Republicans are going to hate this price tag, huh?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, they're definitely expected to balk at it. But interestingly, some progressives, like Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, are, uh, actually saying it's not enough.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, they're definitely expected to balk at it. But interestingly, some progressives, like Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, are, uh, actually saying it's not enough.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While Republicans are sure to balk at the price tag and the potential repeal of many of President Trumps tax cuts for big companies and wealthy individuals to pay for the plan, some progressives are saying the package should be larger. This is not nearly enough, Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez tweeted Tuesday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Not enough? After that other, um, huge spending bill they just passed a few weeks ago?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not enough? After that other, um, huge spending bill they just passed a few weeks ago?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: The $1.9 trillion American Rescue Plan, right. This is kind of, uh, the next big push after that one.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The one point nine dollars trillion American Rescue Plan, right. This is kind of, uh, the next big push after that one.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The American Jobs plan follows the $1.9 trillion American Rescue Plan, which Biden signed into law earlier this month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, who, like, really stands to benefit if this all goes through? Any specific industries?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, who, like, really stands to benefit if this all goes through? Any specific industries?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Analysts are already pointing to companies that manufacture, um, semiconductors, like computer chips. Intel's stock actually jumped, you know, over 8% after this news.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Analysts are already pointing to companies that manufacture, um, semiconductors, like computer chips. Intel's stock actually jumped, you know, over eight percent after this news.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. So it's like a really, really massive and, um, complicated package.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. So it's like a really, really massive and, um, complicated package.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It is. And, uh, Biden's expected to introduce a second part of this plan next month, specifically for healthcare and childcare. So, more to come.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It is. And, uh, Biden's expected to introduce a second part of this plan next month, specifically for healthcare and childcare. So, more to come.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Biden is expected to introduce the second part of his American Jobs Plan next month. That proposal will include provisions related to healthcare and childcare.
